repnme.cdata!: Burkina Faso - Food Security and Nutrition Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcomes gave mixed results, for
            although project is assessed as satisfactory, with a
            sustainable likelihood, the institutional development impact
            is modest. And, while the performance of the Borrower is
            rated marginally satisfactory, based on the delays in
            meeting credit effectiveness, and on weak financial
            management, the performance by the Bank is unsatisfactory,
            given the fact that supervision missions not only failed to
            include the necessary skill mix, but were not frequent
            enough. Key lessons are as follows. Targeted assistance in
            the form of one-time subsidies for income generating assets,
            will lift beneficiaries out of poverty subsistence, and into
            the cash economy. Consequently, targeted subsidies for
            income generating activities, will in turn promote, rather
            than impede, the development of decentralized financial
            institutions; thus, careful project design would minimize
            overhead costs. A systematic review of the implementation
            arrangements should be undertaken by the implementation team
            for each component, to allow for potential redesign if need
            be, and to focus on management arrangements, which may avoid
            unnecessary expenditures resulting from managing income
            generating activities. It is reinforced that beneficiary
            involvement, though not a guarantee to success, would lead
            to lower costs.

18156291.theme: Nutrition and food security,Child health,Social safety nets,Natural disaster management
18156291.trustfund: TF023001-PRIVATE IRRIGATION DEVELOPMENT,TF023445-FOOD SECURITY AND NUTRITION PROJECT
18156291.majtheme: Human development,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!: Burkina Faso - Food Security and Nutrition Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will at the national level,
            (a) reduce the Government's response time for reacting
            to national food crisis, (b) improve the targeting of food
            security programs to concentrate on low income groups in
            drought-prone provinces, and (c) provide a data base and
            logistic frame for rational decision-making on food security
            and nutritional issues.  The project will provide assistance
            for: (1) an institutional focal point within the Ministry of
            Agriculture and Livestock (MOAL) for food security
            management; (2) an integrated Early Warning Systems, and
            improving the data gathering and analysis capacity of the
            MOAL; (3) income earning opportunities in some of the most
            drought-prone provinces during the dry season and period of
            low labor demand; (4) income generating activities directed
            predominantly at women, which is essential for improved
            nutritional status of children; and (5) a nutrition
            Information, Education Communication campaign to bring about
            behavioral changes in child weaning and feading practices.

repnme.cdata!: Burkina Faso - Food Security and Nutrition Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will at the national level,
            (a) reduce the Government's response time for reacting
            to national food crisis, (b) improve the targeting of food
            security programs to concentrate on low income groups in
            drought-prone provinces, and (c) provide a data base and
            logistic frame for rational decision-making on food security
            and nutritional issues.  The project will provide assistance
            for: (1) an institutional focal point within the Ministry of
            Agriculture and Livestock (MOAL) for food security
            management; (2) an integrated Early Warning Systems, and
            improving the data gathering and analysis capacity of the
            MOAL; (3) income earning opportunities in some of the most
            drought-prone provinces during the dry season and period of
            low labor demand; (4) income generating activities directed
            predominantly at women, which is essential for improved
            nutritional status of children; and (5) a nutrition
            Information, Education Communication campaign to bring about
            behavioral changes in child weaning and feading practices.
